data: Fragment of a marble plaque, broken top, right and below; embedded in a plaster plaque for display purposes, so sides and rear not visible.
Found at the east of Porta Stesichori, close to the Convento del Carmine, it became part of Alessi’s collection (reported by Alessi as one of several find in the years preceding 1833).
Observed by Mavilla at the University of Catania and by Stevenson (Cod. Vat. Lat. 10574) in Antiquarium comunale, later by Korhonen in Magazzino del cortile, Museo Civico, formerly sala VI 104.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, additis graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae inscriptionibus

G. Kaibel, Inscriptiones Graecae Siciliae et Italiae, additis graecis Galliae Hispaniae, Britanniae, Germaniae inscriptionibus, Inscriptiones Graecae consilio et auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae Editae. Volumen XIV., XIV (Berlin: Georgius Reimerus, 1890)
Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione
Kalle Korhonen, Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)
C. Wessel, Inscriptiones Graecae Christianae Veteres Occidentis, Inscriptiones Christianae Italiae (Bari: Edipuglia, 1989)
III. Giuseppe Alessi al chiarissimo segretario dell'instituto archeologico, salute.

Giuseppe Alessi, «III. Giuseppe Alessi al chiarissimo segretario dell’instituto archeologico, salute.», Giornale di scienze, lettere e arti per la Sicilia 42, fasc. 126 (1833): 225–35, http://digitale.bnc.roma.sbn.it/tecadigitale/giornale/UFI0049392/1833/T.42/00000257
Giuseppe Alessi, «Scavi di Catania», Bullettino dell’Instituto di Corrispondenza Archeologica, fasc. 12 (1833): 172–76
Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia
Antonio Ferrua, Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia (Vatican, 1989)
Marta Fogagnolo revised the text encoding, added dimensions, the Italian translation and commentary
Alessi, 1833, III. Giuseppe Alessi al chiarissimo segretario dell'instituto archeologico, salute.
Ferrua, 1989, Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia

2Δι̣ον[υσι. 1-2.] [ζήσασ.]
3ἀμέμπτω[ς] [ἔτη]
4λε´ τελευτᾷ τ[ῇ] [πρ(ὸ) ---]
5νωνῶν Σε[πτ](εμβρίων) [ἡμέ-]
6ρᾳ Κυρίου ἐ[ν] [εἰρήνῃ?]

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photograph;
  • line.1: Kirchhoff, Korhonen: ἐνθάδε κεῖται
  • line.2: Traces of ΔΙ (or ΔΥ) on the stone registered also by Mavilla, Stevenson has ΔΙΟΝ.;
  • Kirchhoff: [ζήσας ἔτη], Korhonen: [ζήσασ-]
  • line.3: Alessi: ΑΜΕΜΠΟΣ, Kirkchhoff, Kaibel, Wessel: ἄμεμπ[τ]ος; Ferrua, Korhonen: ἀμέμπτω[ς];
  • Kirchhoff: [καὶ ἄλυπ]|[ος], Ferrua: [ζήσασα ἔτη], Korhonen: ἀμέμπτω[ς ἔτη]
  • line.4: Alessi, Wessel: λκ; Kirchhoff does not register the numeral; Kaibel: λβ; Ferrua, Korhonen: λε;
  • Kirchhoff, Kaibel, Wessel, Ferrua: τ[ῆι πρὸ -]; Korhonen: τ[ῇ πρ(ὸ) -]
  • line.5: Kirchhoff, Kaibel: Σε[πτεμβρίων]; Wessel: Σε[πτ. ἡμέρᾳ]; Korhonen: Σε[πτ(εμβρίων) ἡμε|ρᾷ]
  • line.6: Kirchhoff: κυρι[ακῇ ἡμέρᾷ]; Wessel: κυρίου; Korhonen: Κυρίου ἐ[ν εἰρήνῇ?]

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Here lies(?) Dionysia/Dionysios, having lived blameless for 35 years. s/he died the [-] day before the nones of September, on the day of the Lord. In peace (?).

Italian translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Qui giace(?) Dionysia/Dionysios, che visse in modo irreprensibile per 35 anni. Morì [-] giorni prima delle None di Settembre nel giorno del Signore. In pace (?).

commentary

The restoration of the ἐνθάδε κεῖται formula at l. 1 is highly probable since this is the most frequent structure in Christian epitaphs in Catania, followed by the participle of ζάω to express the age of the deceased and by the verb τελευτάω to specify the date of death (the examples without the ἐνθάδε κεῖται formula are rare and usually the name of the deceased follows the verb τελευτάω, as in IG 14.551 = ISic001370). Ferrua considers the deceased to be a woman and restores ζήσασα at l. 2, whereas Korhonen thinks he can identify the deceased with a Διονυσίος or Διονυσία because of the high frequency of these two names in Catania and indeed the space would fit these names. On the use of ἀμέμπτως ζῆν in the Christian epitaphs in Catania, see IMusCatania 208 = ISic003299, IMusCatania 212 = ISic000647 and Korhonen 2004: 111.

Fragment of a marble plaque, broken top, right and below; embedded in a plaster plaque for display purposes, so sides and rear not visible.

marble plaque 17 26 1-6 chiselled Line 1-6 20-25 Interlineation line 1 to 2 not recorded Catina Catania 37.49223, 15.07041 4th — 5th century CE Found at the east of Porta Stesichori, close to the Convento del Carmine, it became part of Alessi’s collection (reported by Alessi as one of several find in the years preceding 1833). Observed by Mavilla at the University of Catania and by Stevenson (Cod. Vat. Lat. 10574) in Antiquarium comunale, later by Korhonen in Magazzino del cortile, Museo Civico, formerly sala VI 104. None

Text based on photograph Kirchhoff, Korhonen: ἐνθάδε κεῖται Traces of ΔΙ (or ΔΥ) on the stone registered also by Mavilla, Stevenson has ΔΙΟΝ. Kirchhoff: [ζήσας ἔτη], Korhonen: [ζήσασ-] Alessi: ΑΜΕΜΠΟΣ, Kirkchhoff, Kaibel, Wessel: ἄμεμπ[τ]ος; Ferrua, Korhonen: ἀμέμπτω[ς] Kirchhoff: [καὶ ἄλυπ]|[ος], Ferrua: [ζήσασα ἔτη], Korhonen: ἀμέμπτω[ς ἔτη] Alessi, Wessel: λκ; Kirchhoff does not register the numeral; Kaibel: λβ; Ferrua, Korhonen: λε Kirchhoff, Kaibel, Wessel, Ferrua: τ[ῆι πρὸ -]; Korhonen: τ[ῇ πρ(ὸ) -] Kirchhoff, Kaibel: Σε[πτεμβρίων]; Wessel: Σε[πτ. ἡμέρᾳ]; Korhonen: Σε[πτ(εμβρίων) ἡμε|ρᾷ] Kirchhoff: κυρι[ακῇ ἡμέρᾷ]; Wessel: κυρίου; Korhonen: Κυρίου ἐ[ν εἰρήνῇ?]

Here lies(?) Dionysia/Dionysios, having lived blameless for 35 years. s/he died the [-] day before the nones of September, on the day of the Lord. In peace (?).

Qui giace(?) Dionysia/Dionysios, che visse in modo irreprensibile per 35 anni. Morì [-] giorni prima delle None di Settembre nel giorno del Signore. In pace (?).

The restoration of the ἐνθάδε κεῖται formula at l. 1 is highly probable since this is the most frequent structure in Christian epitaphs in Catania, followed by the participle of ζάω to express the age of the deceased and by the verb τελευτάω to specify the date of death (the examples without the ἐνθάδε κεῖται formula are rare and usually the name of the deceased follows the verb τελευτάω, as in IG 14.551 = ISic001370). Ferrua considers the deceased to be a woman and restores ζήσασα at l. 2, whereas Korhonen thinks he can identify the deceased with a Διονυσίος or Διονυσία because of the high frequency of these two names in Catania and indeed the space would fit these names. On the use of ἀμέμπτως ζῆν in the Christian epitaphs in Catania, see IMusCatania 208 = ISic003299, IMusCatania 212 = ISic000647 and Korhonen 2004: 111.
